title: 103_hr2241
content: The Child Support Audit Advisory Committee is established. The Child Support Audit Advisory Committee, established by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, will assist in developing revised audit criteria and standards for the child support enforcement program under part D of title IV of the Social Security Act. The Child Support Audit Advisory Committee will assist in developing revised audit criteria and standards for the child support enforcement program under part D of title IV of the Social Security Act, including numeric measures for compliance assessment, defining substantial compliance, determining audit timing, and recommending necessary legislation for program financing and audit effectiveness. The Child Support Audit Advisory Committee, established under the Social Security Act, consists of at least 6 members appointed by the Secretary. Members include directors of state child support enforcement programs, state human services agency commissioners, experts in audit measures, and representatives of child support service recipients. The Secretary or designee is an ex officio member without voting rights. The Child Support Audit Advisory Committee consists of at least 6 members appointed by the Secretary, who do not receive compensation but are entitled to travel expenses. The Secretary provides administrative support, and the Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply. A report is required within 180 days of enactment. The Child Support Audit Advisory Committee, appointed by the Secretary, must submit a report within 180 days of enactment containing proposed criteria for audits emphasizing program outcomes. NEW CHILD SUPPORT AUDIT PROCESS. The Secretary will promulgate new criteria and standards for audits under the Social Security Act, emphasizing program outcomes. Legislation may be recommended to Congress to enhance the effectiveness of audits and penalties for State child support programs. Timing for rulemaking is within 270 days of the Act's enactment. After the enactment of the Act, the Secretary will issue proposed rulemaking for audit criteria and standards within 12 months. Final regulations will be issued after allowing 45 days for public comment.
